p: From Fig. 2, the net CO 2 assimilation rate ( P n, Fig. 2A) and the stomatal conductance ( G s, Fig. 2B) of S. baicalensis were significantly affected by both the temperature and water availability treatments ( p < 0.05), whereas the effects of the treatments on the intercellular CO 2 concentrations ( C i, Fig. 2C) and the ratio of intercellular to ambient CO 2 concentrations (the C i/ C a ratio, Fig. 2D) were not significant ( p > 0.05). In the T 0 treatment, compared with the W 0 treatment, the P n decreased significantly by 40.0% in the W −15 treatment, and in the W +15 treatment, the P n increased by a large 45.3%. With the increase in temperature in the T 4 treatment, compared with the W 0 treatment, the P n decreased by 28.8% in the W −15 treatment, and in the W +15 treatment, the P n increased by 38.8%. However, under the different water treatments, compared with the T 0 treatment, in the T 4 treatment, the P n significantly decreased by approximately 28.3–38.7%. In the T 0 treatment, compared with the W 0 treatment, the W −15 treatment had no significant effect on the G s, but in the W +15 treatment, the G s increased by 1.5-fold. In the T 4 treatment, compared with the W 0 treatment, the G s decreased by 32.5% in the W −15 treatment but the G s increased by 1.5-fold in the W +15 treatment. Under the W −15, W 0 and W +15 water availability treatments, compared with the T 0 treatment, in the T 4 treatment, the G s decreased by 33.1%, increased by 10.8% and decreased by 40.3%, respectively.
